elements.content: Hydrothermal reactions of Mn(II), Cu(II), Co(II), and Ni(II) salts with 2-(1-triazole)-1-hydroxyl-1,1′-ethylidenediphosphonic acid (tahedpH4) lead to four novel metal phosphonates, namely, Mn2(tahedp)(H2O)2 (1), Cu2(tahedp)(H2O) (2), Co(tahedpH2) (3) and Ni2(tahedpH2)2·(NH2CH2CH2NH2) (4). In compound 1, dimeric units {Mn12O2} are linked together by the O3−P1−O1 groups forming an inorganic chain. The adjacent chains are further connected by {Mn2O4N} pentahedra to form an undulating inorganic layer. The inorganic layers are bridged by the triazole groups resulting in a three-dimensional framework structure. In the opinion of the topology, the structure of 1 can be described as an unprecedented trinodal (4.66.83)2(42.62.82)(5.62)2 topological network. Compound 2 shows a pillared layered structure in which the {Cu12O2} dimers are linked together by the O3−P1−O1 groups forming a double chain. The double chains and the {−Cu2−O5−P2−O4−}2 eight-membered rings are further linked through the coordination of O2 and O6 atoms into a layer. The neighboring layers are connected together by the triazole rings, resulting in a pillared layered structure. Topological analysis of compound 2 reveals that it is a unique 3, 4, and 5-connected net with (42.6)2(42.84)(43.6.86)2 topology. Compound 3 exhibits a layer structure made up of Co2(tahedpH2)2 dimer units. Compound 4 exhibits a layer architecture that built from {NiO5N} octahedra interconnected by phosphonate groups and triazole rings. Magnetic measurements reveal that antiferromagnetic interactions are mediated between magnetic centers in all four compounds.

elements.content: After the discovery of crystalline-layered zirconium phosphonates by Alberti and co-workers in the 1970s, the field of metal-organophosphonate chemistry has expanded exponentially and numerous chemists have thrown themselves into the chemistry of metal phosphonates in all its facets. Over the past decades, the assembly of transition metal phosphonates has been of growing interesting not only due to their structural diversity and intriguing molecular topologies but also for their potential applications as functional materials in the areas of catalysis, sorption, ion exchange, sensors, nonlinear optics, magnetism, and so on. However, largely due to the poor crystallizability of transition metal phosphonates caused by fast creation in the synthetic process, there exists tremendous difficulties in acquiring their precise molecular structure and determining their physical properties. So, compared to other coordination compounds using carboxylate or nitrogen-contained heterocyclic rings ligands, there are relatively a small quantity of reports about transition metal phosphonates in the literature. To overcome this problem and produce molecular species, various strategies have been adopted by different research groups: (a) Hydrothermal or solvothermal techniques have been widely used. The rigorous conditions have been proved to be useful for the building of the crystalline metal phosphonates. (b) The additional use of an ancillary ligand not only provides structural stability of the transition metal phosphonates but often induces unexpected variety of their physical and chemical functionalities. For instance, Winpenny and co-workers have pioneered the concept of using a “co-ligand” to maintain some solubility, and thus produced a range of transition metal cages including ligands 6-chloro-2-pyridone and phosphonate. (c) The modification of phosphonic acid ligands with functional groups such as hydroxyl, amino, carboxylate, sulfonate, and pyridyl that can remarkably ameliorate the water-solubility of the final complexes is also a promising way for tuning the crystallizability and structural diversity of metal phosphonates directly by those functional groups.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

After the discovery of crystalline-layered zirconium phosphonates by Alberti and co-workers in the 1970s, the field of metal-organophosphonate chemistry has expanded exponentially and numerous chemists have thrown themselves into the chemistry of metal phosphonates in all its facets. Over the past decades, the assembly of transition metal phosphonates has been of growing interesting not only due to their structural diversity and intriguing molecular topologies but also for their potential applications as functional materials in the areas of catalysis, sorption, ion exchange, sensors, nonlinear optics, magnetism, and so on. However, largely due to the poor crystallizability of transition metal phosphonates caused by fast creation in the synthetic process, there exists tremendous difficulties in acquiring their precise molecular structure and determining their physical properties. So, compared to other coordination compounds using carboxylate or nitrogen-contained heterocyclic rings ligands, there are relatively a small quantity of reports about transition metal phosphonates in the literature. To overcome this problem and produce molecular species, various strategies have been adopted by different research groups: (a) Hydrothermal or solvothermal techniques have been widely used. The rigorous conditions have been proved to be useful for the building of the crystalline metal phosphonates. (b) The additional use of an ancillary ligand not only provides structural stability of the transition metal phosphonates but often induces unexpected variety of their physical and chemical functionalities. For instance, Winpenny and co-workers have pioneered the concept of using a "co-ligand" to maintain some solubility, and thus produced a range of transition metal cages including ligands 6-chloro-2-pyridone and phosphonate. (c) The modification of phosphonic acid ligands with functional groups such as hydroxyl, amino, carboxylate, sulfonate, and pyridyl that can remarkably ameliorate the water-solubility of the final complexes is also a promising way for tuning the crystallizability and structural diversity of metal phosphonates directly by those functional groups.

elements.content: Taking the factors above into account, we introduced the triazole and hydroxyl groups into the backbone of the biphosphonic acid and synthesized 2-(1-triazole)-1-hydroxyl-1,1′-ethylidenediphosphonic acid (tahedpH4) (Scheme ). Clearly, the modification employed on the phosphonic acid can increase ligand’s hydrophilicity and coordination diversity, expected not only to increase the crystallizability but also to achieve novel topologies of resulting transition metal phosphonates compounds under hydrothermal conditions. In this paper, we report four compounds based on 2-(1-triazole)-1-hydroxyl-1,1′-ethylidenediphosphonic acid (tahedpH4) with formula Mn2(tahedp)(H2O)2 (1), Cu2(tahedp)(H2O) (2), Co(tahedpH2) (3) and Ni2(tahedpH2)2·(NH2CH2CH2NH2) (4). As far as we are aware, no metal-tahedp compound has been reported in the literature so far. Compounds 1 and 2 exhibit new types of topologic structures not found in the known metal phosphonates.

elements.content: 2-(1-triazole)-1-hydroxyl-1,1′-ethylidenediphosphonic acid (tahedpH4) was prepared according to the literature. All other starting materials were purchased as reagent-grade chemicals and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on a Carlo-Erba 1160 elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained as KBr disks on a Shimadzu IR 435 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a NETZSCH STA409PC unit at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under an oxygen atmosphere. Magnetic susceptibility data were obtained on microcrystalline samples (35.17 mg for 1, 47.84 mg for 2, 28.76 mg for 3, and 43.49 mg for 4), using a Quantum Design MPMS-XL7 SQUID magnetometer. Diamagnetic corrections were made for both the sample holder and the compound estimated from Pascal’s constants.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

2-(1-triazole)-1-hydroxyl-1,1'-ethylidenediphosphonic acid (tahedpH4) was prepared according to the literature. All other starting materials were purchased as reagent-grade chemicals and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on a Carlo-Erba 1160 elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained as KBr disks on a Shimadzu IR 435 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a NETZSCH STA409PC unit at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under an oxygen atmosphere. Magnetic susceptibility data were obtained on microcrystalline samples (35.17 mg for 1, 47.84 mg for 2, 28.76 mg for 3, and 43.49 mg for 4), using a Quantum Design MPMS-XL7 SQUID magnetometer. Diamagnetic corrections were made for both the sample holder and the compound estimated from Pascal's constants.

elements.content: A mixture of tahedpH4 (0.10 mmol, 0.0275 g) and MnCl2·4H2O (0.20 mmol, 0.0405 g) in 10 mL of H2O was kept in a Teflon-lined autoclave at 200 °C for 72 h. After slowly cooling to room temperature, pink blocky crystals were obtained, together with a small amount of unidentified white powder. The crystals were manually selected and used for physical measurements. Yield: 23.25 mg (28% based on Mn). Anal. Found (Calcd) for C4H9N3O9P2Mn2: C, 11.21 (11.57); H, 2.24 (2.17); N, 10.56 (10.12). IR (KBr, cm−1): 3365(m), 2927(w), 2858(w), 1630(m), 1529(w), 1446(w), 1400(w), 1294(w), 1161(s), 1076(s), 971(s), 852(w), 746(w), 683(w), 636(w), 566(m), 512(w).

elements.content: Single crystals of dimensions 0.15 × 0.08 × 0.04 mm for 1, 0.12 × 0.10 × 0.08 mm for 2, 0.08 × 0.05 × 0.1 mm for 3, and 0.3 × 0.24 × 0.12 mm for 4 were selected for structural determinations on a Ragiku AFC10Saturn72 CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. A hemisphere of data was collected in the θ range of 1.87−25.00° for 1, 1.96−27.49° for 2, 2.07−24.99° for 3, and 2.05−26.00° for 4 using a narrow-frame method with scan width of 0.50° in ω. The numbers of observed and unique reflections are 11 573 and 2040 (R int = 0.0726) for 1, 6527 and 2422 (R int = 0.0355) for 2, 2729 and 1598 (R int = 0.0226) for 3, 11245 and 2069 (R int = 0.0627) for 4. The data were integrated using the CrystalClear-SM 1.3.6 SP3r6 program with the intensities corrected for Lorentz factor, polarization, air absorption, and absorption due to variation in the path length through the detector faceplate. Multiscan absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full matrix least-squares using SHELXTL. All the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the Fourier maps and were refined anisotropically. All H atoms were refined isotropically with the isotropic vibration parameters related to the non-H atom to which they are bonded. The crystallographic data for the four compounds are listed in Table , and the selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table . CCDC publication nos. 693837−693840 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.

Compound 1 crystallizes in the space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit consists of two crystallographically independent Mn(II) ions, one tahedp4− ligand, and two water molecules. The geometry around the Mn1 atom can be described as a distorted octahedron. All six binding sites are provided by O1, N2, O3A, O5A, O1B atoms from three equivalent tahedp4− ligands and one aqua oxygen O8 (symmetry code: $A −x+2, −y+2, −z; $B −x+1, −y+2, −z). The Mn1−N bond length is 2.329 Å and the Mn1−O bond lengths are in the range 2.033−2.299 Å. The Mn2 atom has a distorted tetragonal pyramidal geometry. Four basal positions are filled with O2, O4, O6C and N3D atoms from three equivalent tahedp4− ligands (symmetry code: $C x, −y+3/2, z+1/2; $D x+1, y, z+1). The axial site is filled with aqua oxygen O9. The Mn2−N bond length is 2.195 Å and the Mn2−O bond lengths range from 2.065 to 2.177 Å. All the bond lengths are in agreement with those reported in other Mn(II) phosphonates. Each tahedp4− ligand serves as an octadentate ligand and bridges the Mn atoms through the O1, O2, O3, O4, O5, and O6 atoms from phosphonate moieties and N2, N3 atoms from the triazole ring (Scheme a). The O1 atom acts as a μ3-O and links the two Mn1 octahedra into a {Mn12O2} dimer through edge sharing (Figure ). The Mn···Mn distance over the μ3-O1 is 3.339 Å. The Mn1−O1−Mn1B bond angle is 100.56(18)°. The neighboring dimers are connected together by the O3−P1−O1 units, and therefore an infinite double chain is constructed along the [100] direction that contains eight-membered rings assembled from vertex-sharing {Mn1O5N} octahedra and {CP1O3} tetrahedra (Figure ). The Mn···Mn distances across the O−P−O bridges within the chain are 5.023 and 6.405 Å, respectively. The adjacent chains are further bridged by {Mn2O4N} pentahedra through O5−P2−O6 and O2−P1−O1 units, thus leading to a two-dimensional undulating layer approximately in the ab plane (Figure ). Within the layer, each {Mn2O4N} pentahedron shares the oxygen-vertexes of {CP1O3} tetrahedron with two near {Mn12O2} dimers from the same chain. Synchronously, each {Mn2O4N} pentahedron also shares the vertexes of {CP2O3} tetrahedron with the third {Mn12O2} dimer from the nearby chain. The Mn1···Mn2 distances between chains through O−P−O bridges are 5.096, 5.190, 6.600 and 6.648 Å, respectively. The triazole rings protrude from two sides of the undulating layer and join Mn1 and Mn2 atoms from the neighboring layers using their nitrogen atoms (N2 and N3). In addition, the {Mn2O4N} pentahedra incorporated between the layers also participate in the contacts through the coordination of the residuary phosphonate oxygen atom (O4). As a result, a three-dimensional pillared layered structure eventually comes into being (Figure ).

elements.content: Topologically, each tahedp4− ligand is connected to two {Mn12O2} dimer units and three Mn2 centers through Mn−O and Mn−N bonds. Contrarily each {Mn12O2} dimer unit links with four tahedp4− ligands and each Mn2 ion links with three tahedp4− ligands. Thus, the tahedp4− ligand, {Mn12O2} dimer unit, and Mn2 ion can be defined as a 5-, 4-, and 3-connected node, respectively. On the basis of this simplification, the structure of 1 can be described as an unprecedented trinodal (4.66.83)2(42.62.82)(5.62)2 topological network (Figure ). To the best of our knowledge, no metal phosphonates with trinodal (4.66.83)2(42.62.82)(5.62)2 topology have been reported to date.

elements.content: The structure of 2 is built up of copper phosphonate layers connected by triazole rings. The asymmetric unit consists of two Cu atoms, one tahedp4− ligand and one water molecule. There are two crystallographically different Cu atoms. Both of them have a distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry. The basal plane of Cu1 atom is defined by N2, O3A, O6A, and O1B atoms from three equivalent tahedp4− ligands with the mean deviation of 0.1156 Å (symmetry code: $A −x+2, −y+2, −z+1; $B −x+1, −y+2, −z+1). The apical site is filled with O1 atom with an elongated distance of 2.288 Å. The Cu1−N bond length is 2.061 Å and the Cu1−O bond lengths range from 1.896 to 2.288 Å. The equatorial positions around Cu2 atom are occupied by four phosphonate oxygen atoms O4, O8, O2C, and O5C from two equivalent tahedp4− ligands with the Cu2−O bond lengths in the range of 1.945−2.029 Å. The axial site is filled with the nitrogen atom N3D from the third tahedp4− ligand with an elongated distance of 2.210 Å (symmetry code: $C −x+2, −y+2, −z; $D −x+1, −y+1, −z). All the bond lengths are comparable to those reported in other copper(II) phosphonates. The tahedp4− ligand are fully deprotonated and all phosphonate oxygens are involved in the coordination of the metal centers (Scheme b). The phosphonate group around P1 bridges the Cu(II) ions into an infinite single chain along the a-axis by using two of its three phosphonate oxygens (O1 and O3). The two single chains are cross-linked by the O1 atoms, forming a ladder with the edge-sharing {Cu12O2}dimers as the rung (Figure ). At the same time, the O4 and O5 atoms of the phosphonate group around P2 are coordinated to Cu2 atoms with the constructions of {−Cu2−O5−P2−O4−}2 eight-membered rings dwelling between double chains. The double chains and the {−Cu2−O5−P2−O4−}2 eight-membered rings are further linked through the coordination of O2 and O6 atoms into a layer in the ac plane (Figure ). Anyway, each {CPO3} tetrahedron is corner-shared with three {CuO4N} pentahedra and vice versa within the layer. The neighboring layers are connected together by the triazole rings of the ligands, resulting in a pillared layered structure (Figure ).

Description of Structure Cu2(tahedp)(H2O) (2)

The structure of 2 is built up of copper phosphonate layers connected by triazole rings. The asymmetric unit consists of two Cu atoms, one tahedp4- ligand and one water molecule. There are two crystallographically different Cu atoms. Both of them have a distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry. The basal plane of Cu1 atom is defined by N2, O3A, O6A, and O1B atoms from three equivalent tahedp4- ligands with the mean deviation of 0.1156 Å (symmetry code: $A -x+2, -y+2, -z+1; $B -x+1, -y+2, -z+1). The apical site is filled with O1 atom with an elongated distance of 2.288 Å. The Cu1-N bond length is 2.061 Å and the Cu1-O bond lengths range from 1.896 to 2.288 Å. The equatorial positions around Cu2 atom are occupied by four phosphonate oxygen atoms O4, O8, O2C, and O5C from two equivalent tahedp4- ligands with the Cu2-O bond lengths in the range of 1.945-2.029 Å. The axial site is filled with the nitrogen atom N3D from the third tahedp4- ligand with an elongated distance of 2.210 Å (symmetry code: $C -x+2, -y+2, -z; $D -x+1, -y+1, -z). All the bond lengths are comparable to those reported in other copper(II) phosphonates. The tahedp4- ligand are fully deprotonated and all phosphonate oxygens are involved in the coordination of the metal centers (Scheme b). The phosphonate group around P1 bridges the Cu(II) ions into an infinite single chain along the a-axis by using two of its three phosphonate oxygens (O1 and O3). The two single chains are cross-linked by the O1 atoms, forming a ladder with the edge-sharing {Cu12O2}dimers as the rung (Figure ). At the same time, the O4 and O5 atoms of the phosphonate group around P2 are coordinated to Cu2 atoms with the constructions of {-Cu2-O5-P2-O4-}2 eight-membered rings dwelling between double chains. The double chains and the {-Cu2-O5-P2-O4-}2 eight-membered rings are further linked through the coordination of O2 and O6 atoms into a layer in the ac plane (Figure ). Anyway, each {CPO3} tetrahedron is corner-shared with three {CuO4N} pentahedra and vice versa within the layer. The neighboring layers are connected together by the triazole rings of the ligands, resulting in a pillared layered structure (Figure ).

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in the space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of one Co atom and one tahedpH2 2− ligand. The Co1 atom adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry with the bond angles around it ranging from 81.83(12) to 179.39(12)°. Four basal positions around the Co1 atom are filled with O2, O4, N3C, O4D atoms from three equivalent tahedpH2 2− ligands (symmetry code: $C x+1, y−1, z; $D 3−x, −y, 1−z). Two phosphonate oxygens O1A and O5B from other two equivalent tahedpH2 2− ligands occupy the remaining two axial sites (symmetry code: $A x+1, y, z; $B 2−x, −y, 1−z) (Figure ). The Co1−N bond length is 2.152 Å and the Co−O bond lengths fall in the range 2.035−2.217 Å, which are comparable to those reported in other cobalt(II) phosphonates. The tahedpH2 2− molecule serves as a pentadentate ligand and bridges the Co1 atoms through the O1, O2, O4, and O5 atoms from phosphonate moieties (Scheme c). The remaining two phosphonate oxygen atoms (O3 and O6) are protonated. The O4 atom links the two Co atoms into a centrosymmetric dimer units of [Co2O42] acting as a μ3 bridge (Figure ). The Co1−O4−Co1A angle within this dimer is 98.17(13)°. The Co···Co distance over the O4 bridge is 3.312 Å. The neighboring dimer units are fused together by vertex-sharing of {CoO5N} octahedron and {CPO3} tetrahedron, thus forming infinite double chains along the [100] direction (Figure ). The Co···Co distances across the O−P−O bridges within the chain are 5.084 and 5.103 Å, respectively. The adjacent chains are further connected through the coordination of the nitrogen atom (N3) from one chain to the Co1 atom from the other, hence generating a two-dimensional layer of [Co2(tahedpH2)2]n containing 4-, 8-, and 16-membered rings in the ab plane (Figure ). Between the layers, there exists very strong hydrogen-bonding interactions among the phosphonate oxygen atoms as well as the hydroxyl atoms. The O6···O6G and O7···O1A distances are 2.876 and 2.666 Å, respectively. The O6−H6A···O6G and O7−H7A···O1A bond angles are 149.8 and 179°, respectively (symmetry code: $G, −x+2, −y+1, −z+1; $A, x+1, y, z). A three-dimensional supramolecular framework is therefore constructed by the assembly of [Co2(tahedpH2)2] n layers through strong hydrogen bond.

Description of Structure Co(tahedpH2) (3)

Compound 3 crystallizes in the space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of one Co atom and one tahedpH2 2- ligand. The Co1 atom adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry with the bond angles around it ranging from 81.83(12) to 179.39(12)°. Four basal positions around the Co1 atom are filled with O2, O4, N3C, O4D atoms from three equivalent tahedpH2 2- ligands (symmetry code: $C x+1, y-1, z; $D 3-x, -y, 1-z). Two phosphonate oxygens O1A and O5B from other two equivalent tahedpH2 2- ligands occupy the remaining two axial sites (symmetry code: $A x+1, y, z; $B 2-x, -y, 1-z) (Figure ). The Co1-N bond length is 2.152 Å and the Co-O bond lengths fall in the range 2.035-2.217 Å, which are comparable to those reported in other cobalt(II) phosphonates. The tahedpH2 2- molecule serves as a pentadentate ligand and bridges the Co1 atoms through the O1, O2, O4, and O5 atoms from phosphonate moieties (Scheme c). The remaining two phosphonate oxygen atoms (O3 and O6) are protonated. The O4 atom links the two Co atoms into a centrosymmetric dimer units of [Co2O42] acting as a μ3 bridge (Figure ). The Co1-O4-Co1A angle within this dimer is 98.17(13)°. The Co⋅⋅⋅Co distance over the O4 bridge is 3.312 Å. The neighboring dimer units are fused together by vertex-sharing of {CoO5N} octahedron and {CPO3} tetrahedron, thus forming infinite double chains along the [100] direction (Figure ). The Co⋅⋅⋅Co distances across the O-P-O bridges within the chain are 5.084 and 5.103 Å, respectively. The adjacent chains are further connected through the coordination of the nitrogen atom (N3) from one chain to the Co1 atom from the other, hence generating a two-dimensional layer of [Co2(tahedpH2)2]n containing 4-, 8-, and 16-membered rings in the ab plane (Figure ). Between the layers, there exists very strong hydrogen-bonding interactions among the phosphonate oxygen atoms as well as the hydroxyl atoms. The O6⋅⋅⋅O6G and O7⋅⋅⋅O1A distances are 2.876 and 2.666 Å, respectively. The O6-H6A⋅⋅⋅O6G and O7-H7A⋅⋅⋅O1A bond angles are 149.8 and 179°, respectively (symmetry code: $G, -x+2, -y+1, -z+1; $A, x+1, y, z). A three-dimensional supramolecular framework is therefore constructed by the assembly of [Co2(tahedpH2)2] n  layers through strong hydrogen bond.

elements.content: A better insight into the nature of compound 3 can be achieved by the application of topological analysis. As discussed above, the [Co2O42] dimer unit is defined as a 6-connected node. Similarly, tahedpH2 2− ligand can act as a 3-connected node. In this structure, the ratio of 3-connected and 6-connected node is 2:1. Consequently, this structure is a binodal net with the Schläfli symbol of (43)2(46.66.83) (see Figure S1, ).

elements.content: The structure of compound 3 is clearly distinguished from that of Co3(ImhedpH)2(H2O)4·2H2O. Compound Co3(ImhedpH)2(H2O)4·2H2O has a two-dimensional layer structure in which the Co1 and Co2 atom are chelated and bridged by phosphonate moieties of ImhedpH ligand, hence forming a trimer unit of Co3(ImhedpH)2(H2O)4. These trimers are connected by edge-sharing of the {Co(2)O6} octahedra, resulting in an undulating chain along the c axis. The adjacent chains are fused through the coordination of the phosphonate oxygen atom from one chain to the Co(2) atom from the other, hence generating a two-dimensional layer.

elements.content: Compound 4 exhibits a layer architecture that is built from {NiO5N} octahedra interconnected by phosphonate groups and triazole rings. It crystallizes in the space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit consists of one Ni atom, one tahedpH2 2− ligand and half a ethylenediamine molecule. Each Ni atom has a distorted octahedral environment. Three of its six coordination sites are occupied by O2, O5, and O7 atoms from the same equivalent tahedpH2 2− ligand, while the remaining three positions are filled with two phosphonate oxygens (O1A and O4A) and one triazole nitrogen (N3B) from the other two equivalent tahedpH2 2− ligand. (symmetry code: $A x−1, y, z; $B −x+1, y+1/2, −z+3/2) (Figure ). The Ni1−O(N) bond lengths range from 2.043(4) to 2.230(3) Å. The bond angles around the Ni atom are in the range of 81.10(12)−173.54(14)°. Both bond lengths and bond angles are comparable to those reported in other nickel phosphonate compounds. The tahedpH2 2− ligand acts as a hexadentate chelating and bridging ligand, using four of its phosphonte oxygens, hydroxyl oxygen, and the triazole nitrogen atom (Scheme d). It chelates and bridges Ni atoms by using four phosphonate oxygens (O1, O2, O4, O5) and the hydroxyl oxygen (O7), hence forming a chain containing eight-membered rings of {−Ni−O−P−O−}2 along the a axis (Figure ). The remaining two phosphonate oxygen atoms (O3 and O6) are protonated. Within the chains, each {NiO5N} octahedron is corner-shared with four {CPO3} tetrahedra. The neighboring chains are connected by triazole rings through coordination, leading to a <001> two-dimensional layer structure (Figure ). The ethylenediamine molecules reside between the layers and are hydrogen bonded to the phosphonate oxygens O1, O3, and O4. The N4···O1A, N4···O3, and N4···O4C distances are 2.761, 2.798, and 2.994 Å, respectively. The N4−H4B···O1A, N4−H4C···O4C, and O3−H3D···N4 bond angles are 178.36, 121.54, and 110.8°, respectively (symmetry code: $A, x−1, y, z; $C, x−1, −y+3/2, z−1/2). If the tahedpH2 2− ligand is considered as a 3-connected node (connecting to three Ni(II) ions), the Ni(II) ion can be considered as a 3-connected node, and the structure of 4 can be classified as a (6,3)-connected network with a (63)(63) topology (see Figure S2, ).
elements.clean_text:
Description of Structure Ni2(tahedpH2)2⋅(NH2CH2CH2NH2) (4)

Compound 4 exhibits a layer architecture that is built from {NiO5N} octahedra interconnected by phosphonate groups and triazole rings. It crystallizes in the space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit consists of one Ni atom, one tahedpH2 2- ligand and half a ethylenediamine molecule. Each Ni atom has a distorted octahedral environment. Three of its six coordination sites are occupied by O2, O5, and O7 atoms from the same equivalent tahedpH2 2- ligand, while the remaining three positions are filled with two phosphonate oxygens (O1A and O4A) and one triazole nitrogen (N3B) from the other two equivalent tahedpH2 2- ligand. (symmetry code: $A x-1, y, z; $B -x+1, y+1/2, -z+3/2) (Figure ). The Ni1-O(N) bond lengths range from 2.043(4) to 2.230(3) Å. The bond angles around the Ni atom are in the range of 81.10(12)-173.54(14)°. Both bond lengths and bond angles are comparable to those reported in other nickel phosphonate compounds. The tahedpH2 2- ligand acts as a hexadentate chelating and bridging ligand, using four of its phosphonte oxygens, hydroxyl oxygen, and the triazole nitrogen atom (Scheme d). It chelates and bridges Ni atoms by using four phosphonate oxygens (O1, O2, O4, O5) and the hydroxyl oxygen (O7), hence forming a chain containing eight-membered rings of {-Ni-O-P-O-}2 along the a axis (Figure ). The remaining two phosphonate oxygen atoms (O3 and O6) are protonated. Within the chains, each {NiO5N} octahedron is corner-shared with four {CPO3} tetrahedra. The neighboring chains are connected by triazole rings through coordination, leading to a <001> two-dimensional layer structure (Figure ). The ethylenediamine molecules reside between the layers and are hydrogen bonded to the phosphonate oxygens O1, O3, and O4. The N4⋅⋅⋅O1A, N4⋅⋅⋅O3, and N4⋅⋅⋅O4C distances are 2.761, 2.798, and 2.994 Å, respectively. The N4-H4B⋅⋅⋅O1A, N4-H4C⋅⋅⋅O4C, and O3-H3D⋅⋅⋅N4 bond angles are 178.36, 121.54, and 110.8°, respectively (symmetry code: $A, x-1, y, z; $C, x-1, -y+3/2, z-1/2). If the tahedpH2 2- ligand is considered as a 3-connected node (connecting to three Ni(II) ions), the Ni(II) ion can be considered as a 3-connected node, and the structure of 4 can be classified as a (6,3)-connected network with a (63)(63) topology (see Figure S2, ).

elements.content: The TGA curves of compounds 1-4 were measured from 30 to 800 °C (see Figure S3, ). 1 exhibits three main steps of weight losses. The first and second steps are overlapping and complete at 626 °C. The first weight loss of 6.61% from 30 to 330 °C corresponds to removal of 1.5 water molecules, which is in good agreement with the calculated value (6.51%). The second and third steps are also overlapping and complete at 800 °C, which correspond to the decomposition of the organophosphonate ligand and the collapse of the lattice structure. The total observed weight loss at 800 °C is 35.67%. A mass loss of 4.41% of 2 occurred between 30 and 290 °C, attributed to the loss of the coordinated water molecules (calcd. 4.37%). The mass loss between 290 and 800 °C is due to the decomposition of the organic groups in the compound with a weight loss of 28.64%. The TGA curves of compounds 3 and 4 show two main steps of weight losses. 3 is stable up to 360 °C, after which it begins to decompose up to 800 °C, during which several processes occur: the decomposition of the organophosphonate ligand, as well as the collapse of the lattice structure. The total weight loss at 800 °C is 40.85%. 4 is stable up to 370 °C, after which it begins to decompose up to 800 °C. The first step started at 370 °C and completed at 390 °C, which corresponds to the release of one ethylenediamine molecule. The observed weight loss of 8.91% is close to the calculated value (8.34%). The second step and the first step are overlapping, which correspond to the combustion of the organophosphonate ligand with a weight loss of 31.94%. The final residuals for all compounds are not characterized.

The TGA curves of compounds 3 and 4 show two main steps of weight losses. 3 is stable up to 360 °C, after which it begins to decompose up to 800 °C, during which several processes occur: the decomposition of the organophosphonate ligand, as well as the collapse of the lattice structure. elements.content: The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility data of compounds 1−4 have been measured for polycrystalline samples in the temperature range 1.8−300 K. Figure a shows the χm T and χm −1 versus T plots for compound 1. The room-temperature effective magnetic moment (μeff) is 6.01 μB per Mn, close to the expected spin-only value (5.92 μB) for isolated spin S = 5/2 with g = 2. The decrease of χm T upon cooling indicates a weak antiferromagnetic interaction between the magnetic centers. In the temperature range 5−300 K, the magnetic behavior follows the Curie−Weiss law with a Weiss constant of −16.8 K. The negative Weiss constant also confirms antiferromagnetic exchange between the Mn(II).
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility data of compounds 1-4 have been measured for polycrystalline samples in the temperature range 1.8-300 K. Figure a shows the χm T and χm -1 versus T plots for compound 1. The room-temperature effective magnetic moment (μeff) is 6.01 μB per Mn, close to the expected spin-only value (5.92 μB) for isolated spin S = 5/2 with g = 2. The decrease of χm T upon cooling indicates a weak antiferromagnetic interaction between the magnetic centers. In the temperature range 5-300 K, the magnetic behavior follows the Curie-Weiss law with a Weiss constant of -16.8 K. The negative Weiss constant also confirms antiferromagnetic exchange between the Mn(II).

elements.content: Figure b shows the χm T and χm −1 versus T plots for compound 2. At 300 K, the magnetic moment (μeff) per copper (II) atom, determined from the equation μeff = 2.828(χm T)1/2, is 1.95 μB, which is close to the value expected for an isolated system of S = 1/2 (μeff = 1.9 μB for g = 2.2). Upon cooling, the χm T decreases gradually, indicating that antiferromagnetic couplings are mediated between the Cu(II) ions. This is confirmed by a negative Weiss constant of −15.8 K determined by the Curie−Weiss law in the temperature range 30−300 K.
elements.clean_text: Figure b shows the χm T and χm -1 versus T plots for compound 2. At 300 K, the magnetic moment (μeff) per copper (II) atom, determined from the equation μeff = 2.828(χm T)1/2, is 1.95 μB, which is close to the value expected for an isolated system of S = 1/2 (μeff = 1.9 μB for g = 2.2). Upon cooling, the χm T decreases gradually, indicating that antiferromagnetic couplings are mediated between the Cu(II) ions. This is confirmed by a negative Weiss constant of -15.8 K determined by the Curie-Weiss law in the temperature range 30-300 K.

elements.content: Figure c shows the χm T and χm −1 versus T plots for compound 3. The room-temperature effective magnetic moment per Co atom (6.74 μB) is much higher than the expected spin-only value for S = 3/2 (3.87 μB), attributed to the orbital contribution of Co(II) ion. The susceptibility data between 50 and 300 K follows the Curie−Weiss law with a Weiss constant θ = −35.17 K. Upon cooling from room temperature, χm T decreases continuously until it reaches a minimum of 3.47 cm3 mol−1 K at 18 K. Below 18 K, χm T increases abruptly to a maximum of 4.29 cm3 mol−1 K at 2 K. The upturn of χm T below 18 K suggests uncompensated magnetic moments of the system arising from spin canting of the antiferromagnetically coupled Co(II) ions.

The upturn of χm T below 18 K suggests uncompensated magnetic moments of the system arising from spin canting of the antiferromagnetically coupled Co(II) ions.

elements.content: Figure d shows the χm T and χm −1 versus T plots for compound 4. At 300 K, the observed effective magnetic moment, calculated from μeff = 2.828(χm T)1/2, is 3.16 μB, close to the expected value (3.11 μB) for spin S = 1 with g = 2.2. On cooling from room temperature, the χm T value decreases smoothly, indicating a dominant antiferromagnetic interaction between the magnetic centers. The magnetic susceptibility above 10 K obeys the Curie−Weiss law with a Weiss constant θ = −6.99 K.

elements.content: Through hydrothermal reactions of Mn(II), Cu(II), Co(II), and Ni(II) salts with 2-(1-triazole)-1-hydroxyl-1,1′-ethylidenediphosphonic acid, four compounds namely Mn2(tahedp)(H2O)2 (1), Cu2(tahedp)(H2O) (2), Co(tahedpH2) (3), and Ni2(tahedpH2)2·(NH2CH2CH2NH2) (4) have been obtained. The structure of 1 can be described as an unprecedented trinodal (4.66.83)2(42.62.82)(5.62)2 topological network not found in other metal phosphonates to date. Topological analysis of compound 2 reveals that it is a unique 3, 4, and 5-connected net with (42.6)2(42.84)(43.6.86)2 topology. Compounds 3 and 4 all exhibit a layer structure. Magnetic measurements reveal that antiferromagnetic interactions are mediated between magnetic centers in all four compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Through hydrothermal reactions of Mn(II), Cu(II), Co(II), and Ni(II) salts with 2-(1-triazole)-1-hydroxyl-1,1'-ethylidenediphosphonic acid, four compounds namely Mn2(tahedp)(H2O)2 (1), Cu2(tahedp)(H2O) (2), Co(tahedpH2) (3), and Ni2(tahedpH2)2⋅(NH2CH2CH2NH2) (4) have been obtained. The structure of 1 can be described as an unprecedented trinodal (4.66.83)2(42.62.82)(5.62)2 topological network not found in other metal phosphonates to date. Topological analysis of compound 2 reveals that it is a unique 3, 4, and 5-connected net with (42.6)2(42.84)(43.6.86)2 topology. Compounds 3 and 4 all exhibit a layer structure. Magnetic measurements reveal that antiferromagnetic interactions are mediated between magnetic centers in all four compounds.

A mixture of tahedpH4 (0.10 mmol, 0.0275 g) and MnCl2·4H2O (0.20 mmol, 0.0405 g) in 10 mL of H2O was kept in a Teflon-lined autoclave at 200 °C for 72 h. After slowly cooling to room temperature, pink blocky crystals were obtained, together with a small amount of unidentified white powder. The crystals were manually selected and used for physical measurements. Yield: 23.25 mg (28% based on Mn). Anal. Found (Calcd) for C4H9N3O9P2Mn2: C, 11.21 (11.57); H, 2.24 (2.17); N, 10.56 (10.12). The second and third steps are also overlapping and complete at 800 °C, which correspond to the decomposition of the organophosphonate ligand and the collapse of the lattice structure. The total observed weight loss at 800 °C is 35.67%. A mass loss of 4.41% of 2 occurred between 30 and 290 °C, attributed to the loss of the coordinated water molecules (calcd. 4.37%). The mass loss between 290 and 800 °C is due to the decomposition of the organic groups in the compound with a weight loss of 28.64%. The TGA curves of compounds 3 and 4 show two main steps of weight losses. 3 is stable up to 360 °C, after which it begins to decompose up to 800 °C, during which several processes occur: the decomposition of the organophosphonate ligand, as well as the collapse of the lattice structure. The total weight loss at 800 °C is 40.85%. 4 is stable up to 370 °C, after which it begins to decompose up to 800 °C. The first step started at 370 °C and completed at 390 °C, which corresponds to the release of one ethylenediamine molecule. The observed weight loss of 8.91% is close to the calculated value (8.34%). The second step and the first step are overlapping, which correspond to the combustion of the organophosphonate ligand with a weight loss of 31.94%. The final residuals for all compounds are not characterized.

Magnetic Properties

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility data of compounds 1−4 have been measured for polycrystalline samples in the temperature range 1.8−300 K. Figure a shows the χm T and χm −1 versus T plots for compound 1. The room-temperature effective magnetic moment (μeff) is 6.01 μB per Mn, close to the expected spin-only value (5.92 μB) for isolated spin S = 5/2 with g = 2. The decrease of χm T upon cooling indicates a weak antiferromagnetic interaction between the magnetic centers. In the temperature range 5−300 K, the magnetic behavior follows the Curie−Weiss law with a Weiss constant of −16.8 K. The negative Weiss constant also confirms antiferromagnetic exchange between the Mn(II).

Figure c shows the χm T and χm −1 versus T plots for compound 3. The room-temperature effective magnetic moment per Co atom (6.74 μB) is much higher than the expected spin-only value for S = 3/2 (3.87 μB), attributed to the orbital contribution of Co(II) ion. The susceptibility data between 50 and 300 K follows the Curie−Weiss law with a Weiss constant θ = −35.17 K. Upon cooling from room temperature, χm T decreases continuously until it reaches a minimum of 3.47 cm3 mol−1 K at 18 K. Below 18 K, χm T increases abruptly to a maximum of 4.29 cm3 mol−1 K at 2 K. The upturn of χm T below 18 K suggests uncompensated magnetic moments of the system arising from spin canting of the antiferromagnetically coupled Co(II) ions.

The second and third steps are also overlapping and complete at 800 °C, which correspond to the decomposition of the organophosphonate ligand and the collapse of the lattice structure. The total observed weight loss at 800 °C is 35.67%. A mass loss of 4.41% of 2 occurred between 30 and 290 °C, attributed to the loss of the coordinated water molecules (calcd. 4.37%). The mass loss between 290 and 800 °C is due to the decomposition of the organic groups in the compound with a weight loss of 28.64%. The TGA curves of compounds 3 and 4 show two main steps of weight losses. 3 is stable up to 360 °C, after which it begins to decompose up to 800 °C, during which several processes occur: the decomposition of the organophosphonate ligand, as well as the collapse of the lattice structure. The total weight loss at 800 °C is 40.85%. 4 is stable up to 370 °C, after which it begins to decompose up to 800 °C. The first step started at 370 °C and completed at 390 °C, which corresponds to the release of one ethylenediamine molecule. The observed weight loss of 8.91% is close to the calculated value (8.34%). The second step and the first step are overlapping, which correspond to the combustion of the organophosphonate ligand with a weight loss of 31.94%. The final residuals for all compounds are not characterized.

Magnetic Properties

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility data of compounds 1-4 have been measured for polycrystalline samples in the temperature range 1.8-300 K. Figure a shows the χm T and χm -1 versus T plots for compound 1. The room-temperature effective magnetic moment (μeff) is 6.01 μB per Mn, close to the expected spin-only value (5.92 μB) for isolated spin S = 5/2 with g = 2. The decrease of χm T upon cooling indicates a weak antiferromagnetic interaction between the magnetic centers. In the temperature range 5-300 K, the magnetic behavior follows the Curie-Weiss law with a Weiss constant of -16.8 K. The negative Weiss constant also confirms antiferromagnetic exchange between the Mn(II).

Figure c shows the χm T and χm -1 versus T plots for compound 3. The room-temperature effective magnetic moment per Co atom (6.74 μB) is much higher than the expected spin-only value for S = 3/2 (3.87 μB), attributed to the orbital contribution of Co(II) ion. The susceptibility data between 50 and 300 K follows the Curie-Weiss law with a Weiss constant θ = -35.17 K. Upon cooling from room temperature, χm T decreases continuously until it reaches a minimum of 3.47 cm3 mol-1 K at 18 K. Below 18 K, χm T increases abruptly to a maximum of 4.29 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. The upturn of χm T below 18 K suggests uncompensated magnetic moments of the system arising from spin canting of the antiferromagnetically coupled Co(II) ions.
